```{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)
library(tidyverse)
```

# A tibble can be formed a number of different ways
> By supplying vectors to column names

```{r Column-wise tibbles, include=TRUE}
call.centers.tb <- 
  tibble(
    City = c(
      "Dhaka",
      "Franklin",
      "Dublin",
      "Stuttgart"
    ),
    Country = c(
      "Bangladesh",
      "United States",
      "Ireland",
      "Deutschland"
    ),
    Population = c(
      14400000,
      74794,
      527612,
      612441 
    ),
    Square.Miles = c(
      118.3,
      30.12,
      44.4,
      80.06
    ),
    Population.Density = Population/Square.Miles,
    Employees.Needed = Population.Density/1000
  )
```

```{r}
call.centers.tb
```

> By supplying the headers and the columns manually

```{r Row-wise Tibbles, include=TRUE}
market.research.tb <- tribble(
  ~Group, ~Interest, ~Show.Interest.Types, ~Age.Range, ~Retention,
  "A", "Low", c("animated", "comedy", "drama"), "14-17", 0.12,
  "B", "High", c("action", "suspenseful", "edgy"), "18-35", 0.87,
  "C", "Medium", c("current events", "reality", "crime", "mystery"), "36-65", 0.37,
  "D", "Low", c("current events", "crime", "thriller"), "66-99", 0.01
)

market.research.tb
```

> By reading in the data

* Note: The message generated by `read_tsv` can  be supressed with `message=FALSE` in the header

```{r Read in a Tibble, include=TRUE, message=TRUE}
simple.data.tb <-
  read_csv("dataSet.csv")
```

```{r}
simple.data.tb
```
```{r}
names(simple.data.tb)
```
